sn5.10:4.2: Then the nun Vajirā got dressed in the morning and, taking her bowl and robes, entered Sāvatthī for alms.
sn5.10:4.3: She wandered for alms in Sāvatthī. After the meal, on her return from alms-round, she went to the Blind Man’s Wood,
sn5.10:4.4: plunged deep into it, and sat at the root of a tree for the day’s meditation.
sn5.10:4.5: Then Māra the Wicked, wanting to make the nun Somā feel fear, terror, and goosebumps, wanting to make her fall away from convergence,
sn5.10:4.6: went up to her and addressed her in verse:
sn5.10:6.2: “Who’s speaking this verse, a human or a non-human?”
sn5.10:6.4: “This is Māra the Wicked, wanting to make me feel fear, terror, and goosebumps, wanting to make me fall away from convergence!”
sn5.10:6.5: Then Vajirā, knowing that this was Māra the Wicked, replied to him in verse:
sn5.10:7.1: “Why do you assume there’s such a thing as a ‘sentient being’?
sn5.10:7.3: This is just a pile of conditions,
sn5.10:7.4: you won’t find a sentient being here.
sn5.10:8.3: So too, when the aggregates are present
sn5.10:8.4: ‘sentient being’ is the convention we use.
sn5.10:9.1: But it’s only suffering that comes to be,
sn5.10:9.3: Naught but suffering comes to be,
sn5.10:10.1: Then Māra the Wicked, thinking, “The nun Vajirā knows me!” miserable and sad, vanished right there.
sn5.10:13.1: The Linked Discourses on Nuns are completed.
